q5.question: Suppose we have $L_2 = \{b^6\}$. Is $L_2$ a regular language

q6.description:
Let us define a homomorphism $h: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma^*$.
$h(a) = a\quad |\quad h(b) = a\quad |\quad h(c) = b$
$h(L) = \{a^3a^nb^{n-3} | n > 3 \} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n-3} | n > 3\}$
$L\prime = h(L)\{b^6\} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n+3} | n > 3\}$
q6.question: By closure under concatenation, $L\prime$ is regular

q8.description:
Let us define a homomorphism $h: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma^*$.
$h(a) = a\quad |\quad h(b) = a\quad |\quad h(c) = b$
$h(L) = \{a^3a^nb^{n-3} | n > 3 \} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n-3} | n > 3\}$
$L\prime = h(L)\{b^6\} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n+3} | n > 3\}$
$L_4 = L' \cup L_3 = \{a^nb^n | n > 0\}$
q8.question: By closure under union, $L_4$ must be regular

q9.description:
Let us define a homomorphism $h: \Sigma \rightarrow \Sigma^*$.
$h(a) = a\quad |\quad h(b) = a\quad |\quad h(c) = b$
$h(L) = \{a^3a^nb^{n-3} | n > 3 \} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n-3} | n > 3\}$
$L\prime = h(L)\{b^6\} = \{a^{n+3}b^{n+3} | n > 3\}$
$L_4 = L' \cup L_3 = \{a^nb^n | n > 0\}$
q9.question: But, what do we know about $L_4$ for sure
q9.answer: We know that $L_4 = \{a^nb^n | n > 0\}$ is not regular
choices: We know that $L_4 = \{a^nb^n | n > 0\}$ is not regular
